Dear Mr. Rose:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 Be signed and dated.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,

ALLEGATION:
Minor youth was placed at an adult foster home by foster care agency on 6/13/22. A
variance for this placement was request 6/15/22 and denied 6/16/22. There are
concerns at this facility regarding their ability to care for youth with significant needs.
INVESTIGATION:
On 6/29/2022 I was assigned to investigate an allegation made by Complainant that
a youth was placed at an adult foster care (AFC) home despite there being a denied
variance in place. The Complainant reported that there was an investigation at the
AFC home, which didn’t involve this youth, but revealed that this youth was placed
without the required approval.
2

INTERVIEWS
Program Manager – On 7/1/2022 I interviewed Program Manager at the agency.
Program Manager reported the agency currently has three high needs youth for
whom they have had difficulty finding and maintaining placement. She reported
Youth A has been in several placements and was AWOL out of state for some time
before being located in Wisconsin then brought to northern Michigan. While in
northern Michigan, Youth A spent a night at a DHHS office before the St. Joseph
DHHS staff could get there to bring her back to their office. An independent living
(IL) provider was located for Youth A where she was placed; however, that IL
provider requested Youth A be moved. The staff, supervisors and Program Manager
searched for placements and located the administrator of an AFC home where they
had previously placed youth who stated that he had purchased a home for IL youth
and that it would be ready for placement the following Monday or Tuesday. Foster
Care Worker drove Youth A to Flint, where the IL home was located once it was
reportedly ready but called the agency once they arrived stating that the home was
not appropriate as there was no running water, no refrigerator, and it was under
construction. Foster Care Worker was not comfortable leaving the youth there and
sent pictures to the supervisors and Program Manager who determined that the
youth could not stay. The decision was made to direct Foster Care Worker to bring
Youth A to the administrator’s AFC home in Lansing, which did not have any other
residents placed. A variance was subsequently requested but denied due to ongoing
investigations regarding the youth who was previously placed in the home. Program
Manager reported they continue to work with the Business Service Center (BSC)
and providers to locate appropriate placement for Youth A but continue to receive
denials or lack of response. Program Manager added they are experiencing a lack of
placement options, particularly in crisis situation, and they made the decision to
place the youth at the AFC home due to a lack of options.
Foster Care Supervisor – On 7/7/2022 I interviewed Foster Care Supervisor
virtually via Microsoft Teams. Foster Care Supervisor reiterated many of the same
concerns as Program Manager regarding lack of placement resources, particularly
for three youth who the agency is currently assigned. She reported Youth A’s
placement at the AFC home was an emergency placement made after Foster Care
Worker brought Youth A to a home alleged to have been ready for IL youth. When
Foster Care Worker arrived, the home was not appropriate, so she brought Youth A
to the AFC home. Foster Care Supervisor stated that to her knowledge, there were
no other residents at the home. She stated the AFC home provided 1 to 1 staffing for
Youth A. Foster Care Supervisor stated agency staff have consistently been working
with the BSC and local team to locate an approved placement for Youth A. She
reported Youth A moved from the AFC home on 7/7/2022 to a home licensed
through a contracted agency. This placement was intended to be an IL placement,
but the foster mother is now stating she would like it to be a foster care placement,
which is what they are working on today.
Foster Care Worker – On 7/7/2022 I interviewed Foster Care Worker virtually via
Microsoft Teams. Foster Care Worker reported the agency currently has three high
3

needs youth, one of whom is currently at the office. She stated Youth A’s placement
at the AFC home was due to placement crisis, not to due to a lack of efforts. She
stated Youth A returned from being AWOL on a Thursday night and a co-worker
picked up Youth A and brought her back to the office the following day. Foster Care
Worker stated Youth A was triggered by being at the office with memories of being
there and visiting with her mother. She stated they were able to locate an IL provider
in Sturgis which is where they placed Youth A that same day. She stated that she
wasn’t there long before that provider gave notice to have Youth A moved. Foster
Care Worker stated “everyone” made many attempts to locate placement but
received either denials or lack of response. She stated the denials are either related
to Youth A’s needs and behaviors, or the facilities not having openings. She stated
there was a home in Flint that was supposed to be ready for placements on
6/13/2022, so Foster Care Worker and a co-worker brought Youth A to the home on
that date. When she arrived at the home, the home was under construction and did
not have running water. She stated contrary to the owner’s previous reports, the
home had been either purchased or leased just that day. She stated she and the co-
worker left the home and drove around the block to call their supervisors and report
the home’s conditions. She stated the supervisors and Program Manager met then
called Foster Care Worker and asked her to take pictures of the home and send
them back, which she did. Once the supervision team reviewed the photos, they
directed Foster Care Worker to not leave the youth at the home. The owner of the
home stated he had another IL home nearby, so Foster Care Worker brought Youth
A there. Foster Care Worker stated she didn’t even go into the home because it was
not appropriate due to it being all males in the home. The owner of the home then
stated they could bring Youth A to his AFC home in Lansing. She stated when they
arrived at the home, the only other resident was being taken to the hospital by
ambulance and Foster Care Worker does not know if that resident was returned to
the home. She stated the home provided 1 to 1 staffing for Youth A 24/7. She
reported the worker at the home was great and helpful in assisting with Youth A
participating in potential placement interviews. Foster Care Worker reported a
variance was denied for this placement, and she continued to work diligently on
finding an approved placement. She stated that they were trying to do what was best
for Youth A in the moment, by providing the safest place for her to be with what was
available. Foster Care Worker stated Youth A moved to a foster home on July 5,
2022. She stated that the foster mother called her this morning and was reporting
“many concerns.” Foster Care Worker stated she has already sent out 2 more
packets to IL providers as she is concerned this placement won’t last.
DOCUMENT REVIEW
Variance – I reviewed a variance request completed by Foster Care Worker and
Foster Care Supervisor on 6/15/2022, which was denied on 6/15/2022.
Placement Records – I reviewed the placement record of Youth A which
documents 25 placements including licensed foster homes, child caring institutions,
4

hospitals, DHHS offices, and IL placement. Additionally, Youth A has been AWOL
on 5 occasions.
Case Contacts – I reviewed the case contacts in Youth A’s file beginning 6/13/2022
and located 21 calls to placement providers documented.
Photos – I viewed photos of the IL home in Flint which showed a home with bare
wires, uncovered electrical outlets, exposed piping, exposed carpet tacks from
carpet being removed, and areas of what appeared to be mildew and water damage.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12404 Placement.
(1) An agency shall only place a child with an adult who
is legally related to the child, is a legal custodian, or
in a licensed foster home, except as permitted in R
400.12709.
ANALYSIS: The agency staff placed Youth A in an AFC home on 6/13/2022.
They requested a variance approval for the placement on
6/15/2022 and it was denied on 6/15/2022. Youth A remained in
the placement until 7/5/2022.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, I recommend no change in the
license status.
July 7, 2022
